MILITARY TRAINING AT HOPKINS
In a pamphlet by Winthrop D. Lane, which was recently
issued, the facts of military training in colleges were presented,
and compulsory military training was opposed. A number of
well known people signed the pamphlet, including Senator
Borah, the late Senator La Follette, Jane Addams, Oswald
Garrison IIllard, and others of equal prominence.
To us the most striking part of the pamphlet was that
presenting the several views of the R. 0. T. C. to the parents,
the army officers, and the students. We reproduce in toto:
"To American Fathers and Mothers:
"The purpose of this book is not to make soldiers out
of your boys, but to develop them physically, morally and
mentally into the best type of citizens, capable of defending
our flag should an emergency arise . . . With the support
of the parents we hope to get the American boy outdoors
and enjoying these activities . . . which will develop that
hardness and uprightness so common to the pioneers who
founded this free country."— (Italics ours) Junior I?. 0.
T. C. Manual.
"To Army Officers:
"Always remember that the men are the material being
trained and moulded for the work of battle. They should
be handled with the same care that an expert artisan gives
to a fine tool
"So it is necessary that a drill instructor look and act
at all times on the drill field and elsewhere like a trained
soldier, if he is to create in the minds of his men a desire
to be like him. They are being trained to be soldiers, and
the model should actually be before them."--T. D. R. for
use with R. 0. T. C.
"To Students:
"Success in battle, whether attack or defense, is the
aim of all military training. Everything that you have
studied in this course and everything that you will ,study
in the further course of military training, has that great
end in view—success in battle, or victory."—Junior R. 0.
T. C. Manual.
The obvious insincerity of the military authorities cannot
be enlarged upon,—one only need read the italicized lines
above. But, while this goes to create a distrust in the purpose of the R. 0. T. C. throughout the country, we are concerned with the 'Hopkins unit alone.
We hold no brief for the abolition of the student military
training. Some enthusiasts enjoy it, get a great deal from
the course, and undoubtedly have the right to study Military
Science and Tactics as much as we have to indulge our pen:
chant for Sanscrit or the Elements of Heat Engineering. But
why, we ask, does the student have to take R. 0. T. C., or
enter into a supposed course in Physical Training?
It is well known. that the "P. T." at this University has
been a farce for a number of years; the students themselves
refer to_it as `Pitiful Training." A few arm wavings once a
week, a few lectures on personal hygiene, a few ineffective
soccer games under the supervision of a bored army non-commissioned officer,—these have no effect whatsoever upon the
physical well-being of the student. And yet he is offered a
choice of It O. T. C. or this.
The R. 0. T. C., on the other hand, is a bugbear to the
average student. By the time he reaches his sophomore year
he refers to it as "the damn army." He swears at the drill,
at the stupid methods of the instructors, becomes generally
disgruntled, and hastens to turn in his uniform when he is
finally released. The few who do like the work go ahead for
further,training, and it is for these that the course should be
maintained.
"The R. 0. T. C. was established during the war, and is
still continued. If we thought that it were not beneficial,
the course would not now be on the university curriculum."
Thus spoke President Goodnow in an interview in the Evening
Sun. He further intimated that the physical benefit was great.
Ask the men who left the unit at the end of their second year
of forced drilling how much it improved their posture, their
physical well-being. Rather the drilling on cold, dark afternoons, after a day of classroom work, tends •to tire the man,
and prevent full application on his studies for the next day.
In our opinion, certain changes should be made in the
R. p. T. C.-Physical Training at Hopkins. Either a real course
in physical ti aining should be offered, so the student would
have a worthwhile alternative to select instead of Military
Training, or "P. T." should be abolished entirely, and let the
men make a choice between R. 0. T. C. and nothing.
Furthermore, dragooning of bewildered freshmen by army
officers should come to an end. Students should be allowed to
make their choice freely, instead of having bribes of clothing,
money, and academic credits urged upon them when they go
to the Military Office to sign up for one of the two alternative
courses. More than one freshman has been dragged into the
R. 0. T. C. against his will, by tactics more becoming to a
recruiting sergeant than a commissioned officer.
Finally, no one should be illusioned about the object of•
R. 0. 1. C. In spite of the bunk ladled out by the War Department on citizenship, physical training, and training of the
mind, the object of the student training is to build up a large
reserve force, to make soldiers, to teach men to win battles.
We call for a remodeling of the system at Johns Hopkins.
We feel that a large minority, if not a Majority, of the students agree with us in substance. And, as one of our learned
ptofessors constantly reiterates, "The rights of the minority
must be protected."

Pardon our snickers.
It may be that a multitude of resigners actually gave this
novel excuse. It may even be that it was the truth in the
case of a few of them. But what about the score who never so
much as thought of the "pressure of studies"? Is it fair that
they, too, should be held up to the scorn and ridicule of their
classmates because of this libelous intimation that they have a
thirst for knowledge? Shudder at their fate, in these gruesome days of Study Prohibition, if the Activities Agents should
ever get on their trail!

We have a faint recollection that not so long ago the NEWSLETTEn -indicted" itself in an editorial, and formally announced
that it had become "radical."
To our knowledge, the pressure of studies" cliche was
used at so late a date as 'December 4th. And also, to our
knowledge, it had nothing to do with what the person in question said or the reason he resigned.
It is true that this explanation is the conventional, the
correct, the Hopkins-spirited thing to say. But is it the most
enlightening? Resignations are not frequent at a place like
Hopkins, where activities honors are bitterly contested ;—would
it not be interesting, perhaps valuable, to know the whys and
wherefores of the infrequent withdrawals?
*
*
Of course, this matter is itself a comparatively insignificant one. But it is typical of a whole tribe of similar empty
space-fillers.
Tf such trite meaninglessnesses as this were ruthlessly
blue-pencilled, the work of the staff would be almost doubled.
but the NEwS-LETTER would be a vastly better paper.
Why not a Blacklist for such expressions, Mr. Editor?
Here's a starter: of course, to be excepted in those rare instances
where it happens to tell the truth.
*
*
Since our own absolute inexperience at running a newspaper has made us a competent critic of the subject, we may
as well go on to say that the NEWS-LETTER has shown much
improvement of late. We refer particularly to the increased
number of really featureable -feature stories." They have
added much to the interest and attractiveness of the paper.
Except for these articles, and others in which the local angle
is so pronounced thdt they are practically feature stories, the
functions of the NEW'S-LETTER could 'be largely assumed by the
Daily Bulletin.
Those responsible. for the increased number and improved
character of these stories are to be congratulated on their originality and their courage in relying on their own sense of news
values.
It would be unheard of not to "add a word of caution at
this point."
Our purely superfluous "don't," in this matter of features,
is exemplified by the article in The Sun, Saturday the 12th,
headed "Dr. Boas Condemns Ban on Modernists." It is true
fhat Dr. Boas did spend a minute or two condemning what
Mr. Schuler is quoted as saying. But the half-column article
says nothing about the lecture which preceded this answer to a
question from the audience, beyond mentioning the fact that
it was called "A Defense of the Fine Arts."

The Women's Intercollegiate
News Association held its Tenth
Annual Conference at Smith College recently. The question of the
inferiority of a woman's college
newspaper to a man's college
newspaper was discussed. It was
said that the women take too
much for granted and write for
the most part on the smaller issues, while the men get an earlier
view in newspaper work, and for
this reason get a larger perspective in the writing of editorials.
The conference was addressed
by Frederick Allden, a member of
the editorial staff of Harper's
Magazine; Miss Katherine Knight,
of the advertising department of
the Curtiss Publishing Company;
and Douglas Haskell, editor of
the New Student.

and compulsory military training was opposed. A number of
well known people signed the pamphlet, including Senator
Borah, the late Senator La Follette, Jane Addams, Oswald
Garrison IIllard, and others of equal prominence.
To us the most striking part of the pamphlet was that
presenting the several views of the R. 0. T. C. to the parents,
the army officers, and the students. We reproduce in toto:
"To American Fathers and Mothers:
"The purpose of this book is not to make soldiers out
of your boys, but to develop them physically, morally and
mentally into the best type of citizens, capable of defending
our flag should an emergency arise . . . With the support
of the parents we hope to get the American boy outdoors
and enjoying these activities . . . which will develop that
hardness and uprightness so common to the pioneers who
founded this free country."— (Italics ours) Junior I?. 0.
T. C. Manual.
"To Army Officers:
"Always remember that the men are the material being
trained and moulded for the work of battle. They should
be handled with the same care that an expert artisan gives
to a fine tool
"So it is necessary that a drill instructor look and act
at all times on the drill field and elsewhere like a trained
soldier, if he is to create in the minds of his men a desire
to be like him. They are being trained to be soldiers, and
the model should actually be before them."--T. D. R. for
use with R. 0. T. C.
"To Students:
"Success in battle, whether attack or defense, is the
aim of all military training. Everything that you have
studied in this course and everything that you will ,study
in the further course of military training, has that great
end in view—success in battle, or victory."—Junior R. 0.
T. C. Manual.
The obvious insincerity of the military authorities cannot
be enlarged upon,—one only need read the italicized lines
above. But, while this goes to create a distrust in the purpose of the R. 0. T. C. throughout the country, we are concerned with the 'Hopkins unit alone.
We hold no brief for the abolition of the student military
training. Some enthusiasts enjoy it, get a great deal from
the course, and undoubtedly have the right to study Military
Science and Tactics as much as we have to indulge our pen:
chant for Sanscrit or the Elements of Heat Engineering. But
why, we ask, does the student have to take R. 0. T. C., or
enter into a supposed course in Physical Training?
It is well known. that the "P. T." at this University has
been a farce for a number of years; the students themselves
refer to_it as `Pitiful Training." A few arm wavings once a
week, a few lectures on personal hygiene, a few ineffective
soccer games under the supervision of a bored army non-commissioned officer,—these have no effect whatsoever upon the
physical well-being of the student. And yet he is offered a
choice of It O. T. C. or this.
The R. 0. T. C., on the other hand, is a bugbear to the
average student. By the time he reaches his sophomore year
he refers to it as "the damn army." He swears at the drill,
at the stupid methods of the instructors, becomes generally
disgruntled, and hastens to turn in his uniform when he is
finally released. The few who do like the work go ahead for
further,training, and it is for these that the course should be
maintained.
"The R. 0. T. C. was established during the war, and is
still continued. If we thought that it were not beneficial,
the course would not now be on the university curriculum."
Thus spoke President Goodnow in an interview in the Evening
Sun. He further intimated that the physical benefit was great.
Ask the men who left the unit at the end of their second year
of forced drilling how much it improved their posture, their
physical well-being. Rather the drilling on cold, dark afternoons, after a day of classroom work, tends •to tire the man,
and prevent full application on his studies for the next day.
In our opinion, certain changes should be made in the
R. p. T. C.-Physical Training at Hopkins. Either a real course
in physical ti aining should be offered, so the student would
have a worthwhile alternative to select instead of Military
Training, or "P. T." should be abolished entirely, and let the
men make a choice between R. 0. T. C. and nothing.
Furthermore, dragooning of bewildered freshmen by army
officers should come to an end. Students should be allowed to
make their choice freely, instead of having bribes of clothing,
money, and academic credits urged upon them when they go
to the Military Office to sign up for one of the two alternative
courses. More than one freshman has been dragged into the
R. 0. T. C. against his will, by tactics more becoming to a
recruiting sergeant than a commissioned officer.
Finally, no one should be illusioned about the object of•
R. 0. 1. C. In spite of the bunk ladled out by the War Department on citizenship, physical training, and training of the
mind, the object of the student training is to build up a large
reserve force, to make soldiers, to teach men to win battles.
We call for a remodeling of the system at Johns Hopkins.
We feel that a large minority, if not a Majority, of the students agree with us in substance. And, as one of our learned
ptofessors constantly reiterates, "The rights of the minority
must be protected."
